channel.title: flood element on Nicole van der Hoeven
channel.description: Recent content in flood element on Nicole van der Hoeven

item.title: Cuándo JMeter no alcanza: Pruebas de carga simulando navegadores
item.description: Aquí está el video de mi presentación en JMeter Scripting Day, un evento organizado por JMeter en Español el 31 de Oktubre, 2020. Y la versión audio: Introducción Hola a todos! Yo soy Nicole van der Hoeven, y soy performance tester. JMeter es una de mis herramientas favoritas porque es gratis, simple, y por muchos casos hace exactamente lo que quiero y no más. Sin embargo, como performers es parte de nuestro trabajo elegir la herramienta adecuada para cada proyecto, y hay que admitir que hay situaciones en que JMeter simplemente no es suficiente.

item.title: Pros and Cons of API load testing
item.description: Originally posted here. ‍API load testing is one of the most popular ways to run a load test because of the number of open source and commercial load testing tools available on the market that support it. Creating a script to hit your application’s API endpoints is the traditional approach to load testing, but it’s not the only one. Here are some things to consider when deciding whether or not API load testing is right for your application.

item.title: Ask a Flooder 17: How do I use unique test data on Element?
item.description: Originally posted on Tricentis Flood. In this video, I talk about how to ensure that Flood Element uses unique test data, using the example of a customer wanting to script unique logins for his application. Or listen to the audio version instead: Transcript: Hi everyone, Nicole van der Hoeven here again back with another Ask a Flooder, and this week’s question is a follow-up question from last week.

item.title: Ask a Flooder 16: How do I use test data with Element?
item.description: Originally posted on Tricentis Flood. In this video, I discuss how to make your load testing scripts more realistic by including test data. The load testing tool I use is Flood Element, but you can apply these principles to any tool. You’ll find a copy of the Element script I used below. ‍ And, if you prefer, here’s the audio version: Transcript Hi everyone, Nicole van der Hoeven here back with another Ask a Flooder, and this time the question is: How do I use test data with Flood Element?

item.title: Ask a Flooder 15: How do I install Element?
item.description: Originally posted here. In this Flood Element tutorial, I demonstrate the steps required to install Flood Element, including dependencies it requires. Flood Element is an open-source browser-based load testing tool created by Tricentis Flood. Learn more about Flood Element Installation instructions for NodeJS Installation instructions for Yarn Installation instructions for Element Video: Getting Started with Element Guides: Using Element with Flood‍ Audio version here: Transcript Hi everyone, Nicole van der Hoeven here again, back with another Ask a Flooder, and today’s question is: “How do I install Element?

item.title: Ask a Flooder 09: What are the best tools for load testing?
item.description: Originally posted here. One of our most commonly-asked questions is: “What are the best tools for load testing?” The answer will depend on a few things: your reason for load testing, the application you want to test, what kind of load testing you want to carry out, your team’s experience with scripting, and how many virtual users you want to run. Note: In this video, I say that traditional load testing tools can’t simulate requests that are triggered by interactions on the client-side.

item.title: Ask a Flooder 05: How do I get started with Flood Element?
item.description: Originally posted here. On this Ask a Flooder, I talk about getting started with Flood Element. Element is an open-source tool that is a good Selenium alternative for browser-based load testing. It runs Puppeteer under the hood to drive real browsers at scale and can be paired with Flood for cloud load testing. ‍ TRANSCRIPT: If you’re sold on browser-based load testing and want to get started on Element, I think the easiest way to do that is by going to element.

item.title: FOMO and performance testing: Why Robinhood went down
item.description: Originally posted here. Angry customers flocked to the internet when the Robinhood investment brokerage app went down last Monday and part of Tuesday, leaving them unable to trade stocks on a day where Wall Street reported historic gains. Could this have been prevented? The answer is yes. Applications should always be assessed for risk and tested accordingly. Risk-based load testing helps unearth problems that would otherwise only surface in production.
